A resale vending machine full of barely-held-together RCS Intake Systems, clearly unscrupulously ripped from ship subsystems to be resold. Blackbeard's notoriously indifferent to the quality of his work, especially if the Holden Patch applied over the previous Kiosk's logo has anything to say, but he can always be expected to have a few choice pieces.
The Asura, the epitome of intake regulators. Produces thrust by taking cold compressed gas (usually N2) from an internal canister and passing it to onboard thrusters.

An in-house Reaction Control System(RCS) intake regulator by Van Buren. Designed for use in Van Buren vessels exclusively, this unit boasts slightly lower performance specs compared to the Hydra, but at a lower weight.

A mass market Reaction Control System (RCS) intake regulator by Weber. Introduced as a first offering after the success of the laser torch, Weber was never quite able to reach the widespread acclaim of their contemporaries in the field.

A mass market Reaction Control System (RCS) intake regulator by A'kyer Aeronautics.  A full pillar-style intake system, this intake directly pipes propellent into the floor and to the RCS clusters, cutting down bulky machinery. The incredibly dense nature of this intake and the additional piping required results in further weight increases.

A niche Reaction Control System(RCS) intake regulator by Sokol. Designed as a replacement for the mass-market model RCS intakes in use by the majority of Sokol vessels, the Varmint is a bulkier, albiet lighter weight, alternative to the coveted Miura Hydra.
